description: From Middle French interposer, influenced by poser (“to place, put”), from Latin interpōnō, from inter (“between”) + pōnō (“to place, put”).

verbs.description: interpose (third-person singular simple present interposes, present participle interposing, simple past and past participle interposed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To insert something (or oneself) between other things.
examples: to interpose a screen between the eye and the light

entries.meaning: (transitive) To interrupt a conversation by introducing a different subject or making a comment.
examples: “A beautiful country!”“I suppose it is. Everybody says so.”“Your cousin Feenix raves about it, Edith,” interposed her mother from her couch.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be inserted between parts or things; to come between.
(intransitive) To intervene in a dispute, or in a conversation.
